noun.description: A breach of a law or rule; an illegal act.
examples: neither offense violates any federal law

noun.description: Annoyance or resentment brought about by a perceived insult to or disregard for oneself or one's standards or principles.
examples: I didn't intend to give offense
he went out, making it clear he'd taken offense

noun.description: The action of attacking someone or something.

phrases: Well, no offense, but if that is the case, then I want my money back.
Yes, I'd even say it has the edge over London - no offense of course.
And they're very raunchy and loud and that's just my opinion so, please, no offense.
This is just a gentle reminder of course, no offence.
There is such a thing as bad poetry, and, no offense, but I've read a fair it of it on here.
origin: Late Middle English: from Old French offens misdeed, from Latin offensus annoyance, reinforced by French offense, from Latin offensa a striking against, a hurt, or displeasure; based on Latin offendere strike against.
